p: The identification of cultivable spore-forming isolates by 16S rDNA sequencing from the soil samples resulted in Paenibacillus and Bacillus sp. The relative abundance of Bacillus sp. in the microbial community in heavy crude oil sludge was reported in Saudi Arabia, Oman, and Nigeria. [ 41â€“ 43]. Bacillus and Paenibacillus sp. which were relatively abundant in the oil fields can be recommended to be chosen as candidates for hydrocarbon utilization study. One of our isolates, Paenibacillus ehimensis BS1, showed maximum growth in presence of heavy oil and biotransformed it to lighter aliphatic and aromatic compounds demonstrating its potential in EOR and environmental bioremediation under aerobic and anaerobic reservoir conditions [ 11].
